As per dorian birsan, I am entering this bug. I have tried on several occasions
and several ways to update my Eclipse version 3.0.0 to 3.0.1. In every case the
outcome was the same, Eclipse will not run. I can make it run by deleting the
configuration directory, but then it thinks it is still in version 3.0.0 and
continues to ask me if I want to update. I also end up with both the 3.0.0 and
the 3.0.1 versions of the files being loaded and who knows what kind of problems
that will create.

that indicates that the application id was not found. And this is in the

eclipse.buildId=I200406251208

which is the buildId for 3.0.0.

I will be entering a seperate bug in Platform Update as per dorian birsan for
the rest of the issues.

Updating the config.ini is not trivial since its content might have been 
customized by people shipping products on top of eclipse. Therefore if we were 
to override this file, serious problems would occur.

There is two possible solutions to this. One is to provide a special installer 
that carefully add to the config.ini, and the other is for startup / osgi to 
build the configuration from several config.ini like files from the 
configuration folder. 

This would ensure that the eclipse base can be updated without causing problems 
to other products.

Um, you couldn't just read in the file, find the line that starts with
eclipse.buildId= and just replace it with a new eclipse.buildId= line then
resave the file? How complicated does it need to be?

I think build.id is just a particular case. I can describe a few scenarios in 
which osgi.bundles need to be update with the correct versions.

Note that you are still running eclipse.exe, startup.jar, etc. from the 
original build, as they are not updated by the update manager. As a matter of 
fact, I don't see an easy way to update those.

Back to build id: what happens if you decide to revert to a previous 
configuration (3.0.0 in this case)? Then you have to record the fact that you 
made this change to config.ini, and revert the change as well. Currently only 
features/plugins are being reverted to.

This is not to make the problem appear harder than it is (it should not be 
hard, as Ed said), but there is always something else that must be taken into 
account. To me, the build id is the least worrisome of all these, and I would 
not have in config.ini, but somewhere else (in a feature/plugin manifest, etc.)
